title: A Lasting Ripple Effect: The Advancement of Women During the Nixon Administration - Richard Nixon Foundation
content:
A lasting legacy of Richard Nixon’s presidency is the advancement of women. Among the notable outcomes of this dedicated effort by the Nixon administration was tripling the hiring of women in the Executive Branch.

During the first year of his presidency, Nixon began an initiative to place women in positions in the federal government. Scholars, administration members, and representatives from corporate America were gathered to form The President’s Task Force for Women’s Rights and Responsibilities. In December of 1969 the task force issued a 33-page report with five key recommendations to change the course of women’s rights and employment in the United States, beginning at the federal level.

Barbara Hackman Franklin, one of the first-ever female graduates of Harvard Business School and an executive at Citibank, was tapped by Fred Malek, Special Assistant to the President for Personnel, to lead what would be the first-ever concerted effort to put women on an equal employment footing with men.

title: Delayed school renos threaten 'ripple effect' in Tuktoyaktuk - Cabin Radio
content:
Tuktoyaktuk’s MLA says delays to renovation work at the community’s school risk depriving students and residents of the space they need.

Jackie Jacobson wants the NWT government to bring in four portable classrooms that would free up Mangilaluk School’s new gym for the start of the next academic year in September.

The gym is currently serving as a teaching space while classrooms elsewhere in the school are renovated.

Ultimately, the renovations will give the school a much larger gym than was previously the case, with a library, kitchen and other facilities replacing the former gym. The school says it will also be better equipped to serve its 240 or so students from junior kindergarten to Grade 12.

A 2021 schedule had estimated that virtually all of the work would be complete by this month. Jacobson, whose Nunakput electoral district includes Tuk, said the work was expected to cost more than $30 million.

Speaking in the legislature on Tuesday, Jacobson said the school was now forced to try renting space elsewhere in Tuk – at churches or the community hall – while awaiting the completion of refurbishment work.

He said bringing in portable classrooms represented a better alternative than taking up community spaces that ought to be used by others, and the portable units could be added to Tuk’s housing stock afterward.

“This is supposed to be a good news story, but now it’s nothing but headaches,” Jacobson said.

“It has a ripple effect on my students and community. There’s no gym? Mental health issues. It ripples right across the community as a whole, having no gym.”

Infrastructure minister Diane Archie said the GNWT has no spare portables it can send nor the budget to pay for any new ones.

“We are working with the contractor to be able to get an updated schedule so that we can share that with the community,” Archie said.

The minister said her department was working with the contractor to “allow the gym to be open at the start of the school year.”

title: Ripple effects on economy from Pactiv Evergreen paper mill closure estimated to be $500M - WLOS
content:
The closure of the Pactiv Evergreen paper mill in Canton is expected to have a significant economic impact on the area. The paper mill, set to close in late May or early June, employs hundreds of workers and has an annual payroll of about $140 million.

According to Haywood County Economic Development Director David Francis, the loss of that infusion into the regional economy and its total ripple effect is estimated to be closer to $500 million.

“We are really trying to get our heads around what this ripple effect is going to do,” Francis said.



The 115-year-old paper mill its employees have an average income of $80,000 per year plus benefits. With the loss of about 900 jobs at the plant in Canton and potentially another 200 in Waynesville, the effect could be far beyond the immediate $140 million.

“Five-hundred million was the last estimate we had in about 2019 of their yearly impact in the economy,” Francis said.

That ripple effect includes goods, like wood pulp, provided by the local logging industry, and services, like trucking and rail, that help get the product to market. However, according to , the ripple effect can be even greater.



“Any time you take something that has several hundred million dollars in annual economic impact out of your economy, that's not good,” executive director Nathan Ramsey said.

The expended ripples will include everything from grocery stores and local small businesses to health care providers. According to Francis, the effect of the impending closure has already resulted in the closure of another local business that serves the mill.

“We just learned a company in Cherokee County is going to be closing down due to their contract with Evergreen,” Francis said.

For most workers, the loss of their jobs will mean entering a job market that many haven’t experienced in decades. According to the Asheville/Buncombe County Chamber of Commerce, there continue to be more jobs in the area than available workers.



Though this may bode well for some Evergreen employees, it may also be a challenge.

According to Ramsey, “The challenge is, those jobs (at Evergreen) pay very well. So, the likelihood that someone can get a job paying them as well as Evergreen, in some cases, they will be able to do that. In other cases, they may struggle.”

Haywood County is already working with various economic groups across the region to help soften the landing for those soon-to-be displaced workers. Along with job retraining resources, they are also building a website to help Evergreen's many workers better navigate the jobs market.

The Asheville metropolitan area has a $24 billion annual economy that, according to Land of Sky, can certainly weather the economic effects of the closure. However, for those on the front line, it will still likely be a blow.

“I’m bullish on our region,” Ramsey said. “I’m bullish in the future of our community. But, this certainly was a gut punch.”
